subSections.title: Etymology
subSections.text:
According to YuÃ¨ JuÃ¨ ShÅ« (è¶Šçµ•æ›¸), {{och-l|å¤·}} is also the {{w|Baiyue|Yue}} word for "sea". Therefore, {{zh-ref|Schuessler (2007)}} proposes an {{der|zh|aav}} origin; compare {{cog|mkh-pro|*d(n)liÊ”||large river, sea}} (whence {{cog|km|á‘á“áŸ’á›áŸ||large river}} and {{cog|kdt|thlÃ¨Ë||sea}}). Meanwhile, Schuessler associates similar {{w|Hmong languages|Hmong}} forms like {{cog|cqd|tlÌ¥e||river}} (< {{cog|hmx-pro|*gle}}) to {{och-l|[[æºª]]}} "creek, rivulet, rill" instead.

In contrast, Ferlus ([https://halshs.archives-ouvertes.fr/halshs-01182596/file/Ferlus2009_Ethnonyms.pdf 2009]) reconstructs å¤·'s Old Chinese pronunciation as [lÉ¨] and connects å¤· to {{cog|qfa-tak-pro|*k-ri:||Kra-Dai endonym}} (whence {{cog|th|à¹„à¸—||"Tai endonym"}} and {{cog|lic|Hlai||"Hlai endonym"}}). However, Ferlus concedes that such a derivation of å¤· from '''*k-ri:''' "remains speculative, [...] not as firmly established as for Hlai and Tai/Thai".
